DataElement.preferredName: Composite Lymphoma B-Cell Non-Hodgkin Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria Code Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A coded response to questions which are necessary to allow a person to participate in a clinical study that has Coexistence of Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma in the same anatomic site with a non B-Cell as outlined in protocol.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Composite Lymphoma B-Cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Coexistence of Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma in the same anatomic site._The most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  It includes the most frequently seen morphologic variants which are: diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, follicular lymphoma, small lymphocytic lymphoma and marginal zone B-cell lymphoma. -- 2003_Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Coexistence of Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma in the same anatomic site.

Concepts.definition: Coexistence of Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphoma in the same anatomic site.

Property.preferredName: B-Cell Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma Clinical Trial Eligibility Criteria
Property.preferredDefinition: The most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  It includes the most frequently seen morphologic variants which are: diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, follicular lymphoma, small lymphocytic lymphoma and marginal zone B-cell lymphoma. -- 2003:Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Concepts.definition: The most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.  It includes the most frequently seen morphologic variants which are: diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, follicular lymphoma, small lymphocytic lymphoma and marginal zone B-cell lymphoma.
Characteristics which are necessary to allow a subject to participate in a clinical study, as outlined in the study protocol. The concept covers inclusion and exclusion criteria.
